body.body: Copywriter/ACD/Director who only speaks about himself in the third person right here. At no other point will you hear Andy speaking about Andy in the third person. Andy promises.

videos.title: Cheerwine Kreme How We Do It

body.body:
Growing up in the former Soviet Union, a culture that favors uniformity and structured life patterns, Arsenii learned to seek out inspiration from the unsolicited beauty of his surroundings. Influenced by the art that accompanied counterculture movements of skateboarding and underground music prompted him to pick up his first camera. 

After moving to San Francisco he pursued parallel careers in the photo and film industries. This multifaceted education has allowed him to hone a visual language that feels cohesive and real across both platforms. Bringing technical camerawork and cinematic lighting design, to story-driven advertising campaigns, and editorial assignments alike.

image.title: MAR A LAGO SUGAR CANDY MOUNTAIN

videos.title: Sugar Candy Mountain Mar A Lago

body.body:
Born in SF, raised in LA Ben Leavitt is a man who will take anything slung at him from a Thai street vendor who has an inclination towards dark soothing blues (none of that pastel stuff, though).

He loves telling stories and people, so directing is the perfect fit. There’s nothing better than collaborating with wildly creative people. He loves meticulously planning every single shot, and then embracing a completely unexpected direction on set.

hoverImage.title: WTBR Website GIF 022 Light co Launch

body.body:
Tall, unintentionally loud, and originally from Texas, Brian L. Perkins is a former amateur comedian with no dietary discipline who went grey at 17. He has created a 2 mile musical sculpture played by a speeding car with 7 robot arms, met the Unabomber in person, and filmed broadcast commercials with his cell phone.

Brian is a writer, creative director, and director who firmly believes: 1) that you have to buy people’s attention by being interesting; and 2) the best way to do that is often investigating the space where the spectacular meets the mundane. He also misses the era of jingles and is pretty sure your business needs one.

Chris Carmichael aka Carmzone, aka Carmeleon, aka Carmageddon (yea, he started that) hails from the greater Detroit area. When he's not chasing down the best deals from Red Lobster, he's rendering down some out-of-this-world 3D VFX.

David’s subjects range from rock ’n roll heroes to hog hunters, and he thinks some of the most interesting stories are found in the hinterlands, where he spent an Okie childhood being raised amidst an elixir of god, guns and football.

He got his start in filmmaking on projects that included: The Flaming Lips, U.F.O.’s at the Zoo (Warner Bros.), Okie Noodling II (American Public Television) and Sweethearts of the Prison Rodeo (HBO Documentary Films).  His ability to get up close and personal with subjects launched a career that has taken him around the globe on features, brand films, and series for Netflix and Amazon. David infuses a gritty realism and cinematic style into work for commercial clients such as NIke, Levis, VISA, Dodge, Ford, Samsung, Gatorade and Google, and he’s worked on national campaigns alongside acclaimed photographers including Annie Leibovitz, Ben Watts, and Carlos Serrao.

His current projects include films about an aging cult musician revitalizing his career and a peyote roadman trying to save the world.

Jack Henry was born and raised in NYC, and now lives in LA. He decided at an early age he'd rather make people laugh than cry. With the sneaky intention to make you think, he hopes his movies help the world feel a bit more fun. He is six foot four and still can't dunk a basketball.
Jake Pryor is usually sketching some sick lines in a cell animation or designing some weird, magical 2D space. Occasionally, you might catch him trying to lift five times his body weight.

Jeremy's love for film began with shooting his friends skating all over the Bay Area on the hottest Hi-8 camera he could find. He's since picked up bigger cameras and started directing and continues to capture the realness in the stories he finds.

With a background in architecture, Jess is a talented Animator...and Baker. She creates magic on the screen and enjoys baking fresh treats for the team every Monday morning, which leaves us in need of extra naps and walks throughout the day.

Jonathan Flookes (his friends call him Flookes) has been editing in some form or another for longer than he can remember and has spent the last 12 years in the commercial and short films world. The power to tell a story, whether its from a well produced script, or random images taken with an iPhone is something he will never grow tired of.

Descending from a long line of metal workers and Sicilians, Luke Kraman was born and raised in Brooklyn and now lives a happy queer little life in SF. 

His work has been shown on broadcast television, throughout the various corners of the internet, during a U.S. World Cup soccer match and on the world's largest digital billboard in Times Square. He's got a love for storytelling and enough OCD to make each frame as perfect as it can be. When he's not working in advertising or music videos, he's taking care of his plants, baking and shooting medium format photography (often all at the same time).

videos.title: Google Play: Play Your Heart Out

body.body:
Marty is a commercial and documentary filmmaker, photographer, and really cool dad. In fact, THE best. Having started his career in directing proof-of-concept trailers in Hollywood, Marty continues to seek blending a cinematic narrative touch into everything he crafts.

He is a fan of all forms and genres of cinema and believes strongly in its capacity to transcend the expected and not only entertain or sell an idea, but to inspire. His style is both raw and refined and he loves none other than to find a touch of truth in everything he views through the lens so that his work isn’t something to be watched, but something to be experienced.

A filmmaker living in Berkeley, CA. Megan has edited five feature films which have premiered at Sundance and SXSW. She's a natural storyteller with a feeling for large-scale structure and the subtle rhythms of a scene. Deeply invested in every project, Megan is never content to settle, or short of a strong point of view. 

In 2015 Megan was included in Filmmaker Magazine's 25 New Faces of Independent Film.

Olivia is an Emmy-nominated documentary filmmaker based in Oakland, California.

She directs, edits and works on both commercial and editorial projects. Her most recent film, Quilt Fever, premiered at AFI Docs in June 2019 and is a SXSW 2020 Official Selection.

The Perez Bros are a Latinx directing duo specializing in the “lols.” They are currently working on writing a witty bio that demonstrates their capacity for humor. Something funny and clever,but with a relateable twist that winks at the reader. Is it working? Alright, moving on...

Raised on a steady diet of Tim Burton and Saturday Night Live, their work often blends the surreal and absurd in the best kind of way. Their passion for creating quirky characters and unique worlds ensures the audience will begin to giggle before the story has even begun.

They have also won some fancy awards and have been featured on a few showcases, but you can ask their mom about those.

Top ad agencies, big clients, awards, run over by a bus on his bike in NYC but he’s fine – been there. For Peter, every project, big or small, is its own world and deserves its own journey.

Before Peter became a San Francisco based director, he was a commercial editor in New York City. “Being an editor informs almost every decision I make as a director.”

Peter believes every project needs to grow at every phase – during pre-pro, production and post. “Why not keep making it better?” He also believes that you have to make the audience work a bit for the viewing experience to be fulfilling.

Robert Bryant is an award winning Director/DP originally from San Francisco California. He graduated with a bachelor's degree in fine art from the University of California at Davis and after a wonderfully strange and unique series of events he has found his place in the wonderfully strange and unique world of commercial directing. In addition to televisions, computer monitors, smart phones, tablets, magazines and billboards his work can also be found in the permanent collection of the Museum of Modern Art - which makes him particularly happy because of the whole art school thing. 

He’s been called a tabletop director, however, he personally likes to use the term “product specialist”. Some of his favorite tools are Phantom high-speed cameras, special fx rigging, the speakerphone feature on his cell phone and his Arri macro lenses that he used to call his “babies” until his son was born.  He has worked domestically and internationally for clients such as Nike, Microsoft, Proctor & Gamble, Whirlpool and Budweiser.  

He has ridiculously talented and passionate crews on both the East and West coasts and things he would prefer not to go without are family, friends and making stuff every single day. After years of shooting his clients products he decided to create his own and his furniture designs are currently available in showrooms in New York, Los Angeles and San Francisco.

He’s currently finishing a documentary about the best little fireworks store in America and getting ready to shoot another one about donuts. Once or twice a year you’ll find him riding among a pack of vintage scooter nerds with a really goofy smile on his face.
A beautiful reel by the one and only Simon Mowbray. There's nothing the man can't do.

hoverImage.title: WTBR Website GIF 026 Reel Simon Mowbray

body.body: What she lacks in physical size she makes up for in imagination. Syra McCarthy is committed to making her audience question the veracity of their own perception. Another day at the office or five layers submerged in a lucid dream? A director as well as an actor, she uses both identities like Batman and Bruce Wayne working to keep the city of Gotham safe. She loves the power of film and finding the right style to serve the story. Oh, and people and pressure are her favorite, so creatively collaborating on set is pretty much all she wants to do in life.

Victor Ridaura is a Latino, award-winning writer/director, by way of commercial directing, based in Los Angeles, CA. He brings a youthful, multi-cultural viewpoint – from his time spent living abroad – to his creative and energetic productions. His work focuses on narrative storytelling, high-fashion, comedy, celebrity, and lifestyle. His commercial clients include, DirectTV, SONY, AT&T, YETI, MANGO, and BOLON. 

Outside of the commercial realm, Victor’s narrative work has screened and won accolades in festivals around the world. His most recent, DAWN OF MAN - a horror short film he wrote and directed -  screened in over 25 festivals including Academy Award and BAFTA qualifying LEEDS International Film Festival, the HBO presented NY Latino Film Festival, and genre specific fests FILMQUEST, Hexploitation Film Festival, and Panic Fest. His bleak, near future, sci-fi script for SUNDOWN COUNTY, won third place at the 2019 Slamdance Screenplay Competition and was a semifinalist in Screencraft’s Short Screenplay Competition.

videos.title: Yeti Not Inteded for Outdoor Use
